author: By Mark Walker
title: Hundreds of Thousands of Bikers Expected in Sturgis Despite Delta Variant
description: The annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally began on Friday, just as the infectious Delta variant is producing a surge in cases nationwide.
content: Although most large events shut down last summer because of the coronavirus pandemic, the Sturgis Motorcycle Rally forged ahead, panicking health experts as nearly a half-million motorcycle enthusiasts descended on the Black Hills of South Dakota.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter, Taimoor Shah and Fahim Abed
title: Taliban Seize Afghan Provincial Capital Just Weeks Before Final U.S. Withdrawal
description: Zaranj, on the Afghanistan-Iran border, was the first provincial capital to be captured by the insurgents since the Biden administration said it would completely withdraw U.S. troops from Afghanistan.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban captured a regional hub city in western Afghanistan on Friday, officials said, the first provincial capital to fall to the insurgency since the Biden administration announced the full withdrawal of U.S. troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik and Adeel Hassan
title: California and Hawaii step up pressure on workers to be vaccinated.
description: California ordered all health care workers to get their shots, largely removing an option to be tested. Hawaii is requiring state and county employees to be vaccinated or face weekly testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: JPMorgan’s punishment for currency rigging ends.
description: Big banks that were accused of colluding to rig benchmark exchange rates could still face class-action lawsuits.
content: The Federal Reserve has lifted restrictions on JPMorgan Chase for its role in rigging foreign exchange rates between 2008 to 2013.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Biden administration extends a student loan payment pause.
description: The Education Department said that it would be the “final extension” of the moratorium.
content: WASHINGTON — The Education Department announced Friday that it would continue a moratorium on federal student loan payments through Jan. 31, extending emergency relief for millions of borrowers that had been set to expire next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Dancing His Way Into Her Heart
description: Abigail Berger and David Frum, who first met at the University of Colorado Boulder on Saint Patrick’s Day in 2006, honored his mother’s memory on their wedding day.
content: Crested Butte Mountain in Colorado is majestic. That would be reason enough to get married in its presence. But for Abigail Berger and David Frum, getting married there was a sacred celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: New York Man Charged in Scooter Crash That Killed the Actress Lisa Banes
description: Ms. Banes, a film, theater and television actress who appeared in the thriller “Gone Girl,” died on June 14, days after she was struck by a man riding a scooter as she crossed the street in Manhattan.
content: Two months after a scooter driver hit and killed Lisa Banes, an actress who appeared in more than 80 roles on television and in film, including the thriller “Gone Girl,” a New York man was arrested on Thursday in connection with the fatal collision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: New data suggest J. & J. vaccine works against Delta and recipients don’t need a booster shot.
description: The study is the first real-world test of the vaccine’s efficacy against Delta, a highly contagious variant of the virus surging across the United States and much of the world.
content: A single dose of the Covid-19 vaccine made by Johnson & Johnson is highly effective in preventing severe illness and death from the Delta and Beta variants of the coronavirus, data from a clinical trial in South Africa suggest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Orr
title: ‘Ted Lasso’ Season 2 Episode 3 Recap: Youth in Revolt
description: Sam makes a difficult decision, Jamie makes amends and the writers make some dubious choices.
content: This week, “Ted Lasso” begins with perhaps the most sinister of American sitcom tropes: the introduction of a precocious, world-wise 13-year-old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Gopnik
title: Hiroshi Sugimoto’s Jekyll and Hyde Year
description: The artist famous for his riddling photos has turned to old-fashioned function and grace in his design for the Hirshhorn Sculpture Garden. So why doesn’t Washington love it?
content: Hiroshi Sugimoto laughs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Icelandic Saga That Keeps Rita Dove Coming Back for More
description: “Bleak, modernist stuff! And yet revisiting that litany of betrayals and cruelties never fails to stir my spirits.”
content: The former poet laureate Rita Dove, whose new collection is “Playlist for the Apocalypse,” loves the Icelandic saga “Grettir the Strong”: “Bleak, modernist stuff! And yet revisiting that litany of betrayals and cruelties never fails to stir my spirits.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: An Arkansas judge temporarily blocks the state’s ban on mask mandates.
description: Gov. Asa Hutchinson signed the ban into law in the spring but had been trying to modify it recently in the face of skyrocketing case counts.
content: A judge in Arkansas on Friday temporarily blocked a ban on mask mandates, which will allow school districts and other government entities in the state to require face coverings to help curb the spread of new coronavirus infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christian B. Miller
title: Is Your Crush on OkCupid Telling You the Truth?
description: The content on many online platforms turns out to be surprisingly trustworthy.
content: How much dishonesty do you expect when interacting with people online?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Reimagining Our Relationship With Nature Through Art
description: One Australian artist gives us a glimpse into a kinder, more caring world.
content: The creature has the pointed beak and fin of a dolphin but the sagging jowls and stomach of someone getting on in years. Straggly blonde hair trails out of its blowhole and down to its dorsal fin. Its fleshy body is mottled like it’s been in the cold a bit too long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Finding Romance After Ditching the ‘Check-the-Box Approach’
description: Jane Jeong and Byron Hsu were coming off a period of self-reflection after a series of failed relationships when they met two years ago.
content: Jane Jeong and Byron Hsu have always managed to individually achieve what they have set their minds to. But they needed the other to learn what it truly means to love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randal C. Archibold
title: U.S. women’s basketball rolls past Serbia and will play in the gold medal game.
description: The U.S. will make its 11th appearance in the final, playing Japan.
content: TOKYO — The U.S. women’s basketball team has many advantages during the Olympic tournament, including a coterie of W.N.B.A. stars that seem to have a lot of chemistry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Dramatizing the Chernobyl Disaster, for its Survivors
description: Unlike the recent HBO series, the Russian-language feature film “Chernobyl 1986,” now on Netflix, explores the human toll of the power plant explosion.
content: CHERNOBYL, Ukraine — In April 1986, Alexander Rodnyansky was a young documentary filmmaker living in Kyiv. When the fourth reactor of the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Station exploded 60 miles north of the Ukrainian capital, most citizens of the Soviet Union were not informed. It took the government 18 days to share exactly what had happened, but Rodnyansky had been filming the disaster zone from the day after the catastrophe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: A Ride of a Lifetime to a Catskills Retreat
description: Florence Johnson met Dr. Nima Yazdanpanah when she got a ride with him in 2019 to a weekend spiritual retreat in upstate New York.
content: Florence Christina Johnson met Dr. Nima Yazdanpanah in September 2019 when she got a ride with him arranged by the organizer of a weekend spiritual retreat in New York’s Catskills region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Conor Lamb Gets In, and a Crucial Senate Fight Takes Shape in Pennsylvania
description: Democrats sense their best chance to expand their slim hold on the Senate. Republican contenders are outdoing one another courting the “Super-MAGA-Trumpy” right wing.
content: PITTSBURGH — Representative Conor Lamb thinks he knows what it takes for Democrats to win statewide in Pennsylvania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg and Victor Mather
title: April Ross and Alix Klineman of the U.S. Win Beach Volleyball Gold
description: Klineman became Ross’s partner in 2017, after transitioning from a career as an indoor volleyball player.
content: TOKYO — Just four years after making the transition to beach volleyball, Alix Klineman of the United States won the gold medal on Friday with her partner April Ross, who took home her third Olympic medal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Reconsidering Outdoor Travel in the West, as Wildfires Burn
description: Excessive heat and wildfires could disrupt the booming outdoor travel industry, as travelers now have to take a hotter and longer fire season into account.
content: Part of what Katherine Lee loves about Moscow, Idaho, where she lives, are the trails 10 minutes away. She visits with family or friends several days a week to hike or mountain bike, or to have walking meetings with colleagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: Inside One Company’s Struggle to Get All Its Employees Vaccinated
description: At an optical business in New York City, it took months of coaxing, a cash bonus and a weekly testing mandate to persuade 90 percent of the staff to get a coronavirus vaccine.
content: Tiara Felix loves her job at an eyewear store in the Bronx, where she spends five days a week managing customer orders in a back-room lab, surrounded by colleagues fitting and cutting lenses for glasses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Luke Broadwater
title: Democrats Eye Budget to Force Policy Changes, Testing Bounds of the Rules
description: Party leaders plan to include top priorities like immigration and labor policies in their budget plan in a bid to get them past Republican opposition.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats in Congress plan to use their $3.5 trillion budget to try to unilaterally speed through a suite of far-reaching policy changes on immigration, labor and possibly voting rights over Republican opposition, leveraging their slim majorities in a bid to achieve much of President Biden’s agenda in one fell swoop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Here’s what happened in Tokyo on Friday.
description: TOKYO — On the track Friday night, Shaunae Miller-Uibo of the Bahamas powered away from the field in the 400 meters, while Allyson Felix, in third place, won a record 10th Olympic medal.
content: TOKYO — On the track Friday night, Shaunae Miller-Uibo of the Bahamas powered away from the field in the 400 meters, while Allyson Felix, in third place, won a record 10th Olympic medal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Two Belarus coaches are expelled from the Olympics over their treatment of a sprinter.
description: The International Olympic Committee said it had expelled the coaches who were involved in the attempt to force the runner home against her will.
content: TOKYO — Two coaches involved in the attempt to force an Olympic athlete home to Belarus against her will have been stripped of their credentials and expelled from the Olympic Village, Games organizers said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Baltimore Math Professor Who Sold Grades for Cash Gets One Year in Jail
description: Prof. Edward Ennels sold A’s for as little as $300, and also haggled with students over the price for various grades, according to the Maryland Attorney General’s Office.
content: One math lesson Prof. Edward C. Ennels taught at Baltimore City Community College was, according to prosecutors, pretty simple: $150 for a C; $250 for a B; and $500 for an A.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Matt Stevens
title: How do wildfires get their names?
description: Sometimes fire officials get creative. Sometimes not, which is how a fire came to be named "Not Creative."
content: Dixie. August Complex. Not Creative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: ‘One of You Is a Monster’
description: In her latest column, Sarah Weinman explores four new novels, each dark in a different way.
content: It took more than a decade, but David Peace has finally published TOKYO REDUX (Knopf, 464 pp., $28), the final volume of one of my favorite crime trilogies. There are no duds in Peace’s body of work: The “Red Riding” quartet depicts the despair and horror of living in proximity to the Yorkshire Ripper murders, while a looser trio of novels (“GB84,” “The Damned Utd” and “Red or Dead”) offers wily social commentary on what ailed and uplifted postwar northern England, sometimes simultaneously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: The leader of St. Vincent and the Grenadines is hurt during a protest against vaccine rules.
description: The prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines was hospitalized on Thursday after being struck in the head by a projectile during a protest against Covid vaccine legislation in the Caribbean island nation.
content: The prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines was hospitalized on Thursday after being struck in the head by a projectile during a protest against Covid vaccine legislation in the Caribbean island nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and David McCabe
title: U.S. Business Groups Urge Biden to Restart China Trade Talks
description: A letter from influential industry organizations asked the White House to resume negotiations on tariffs and other measures that stalled during a bruising trade war.
content: A group of the most influential American business groups is urging the Biden administration to restart trade talks with China and cut tariffs on Chinese-made goods that had remained in place after the start of the bruising trade war between the two countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: ‘It’s not the same as the fires we were used to’: What it’s like to fight more intense blazes.
description: Some of those who battled the blaze that burned through Greenville, Calif., discuss the growing hazards they face.
content: California is seeing larger and more intense wildfires, putting those on the front lines at greater risk as they attempt to stop raging flames like those from the Dixie Fire that ripped through Greenville, Calif., this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: When Best Friends Become More
description: Kirin Gupta somehow knew she would marry Irfan Mahmud early on in their friendship at Harvard, but she was certain after their first date and kiss.
content: Kirin Gupta wasn’t yet in love with Irfan Mahmud when she entered his number into her cellphone under the label “Future Husband.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: ‘If He Doesn’t Have That Stroke, He’s in the Hall of Fame’
description: For five seasons in the late 1970s, J.R. Richard of the Houston Astros was as intimidating as any pitcher before or since. His legacy is the reverence of the batters who faced him.
content: J.R. Richard never faded. His next to last start was at the All-Star Game in 1980. He was 30 years old, at the apex of his powers, when it all went away. He was the Sandy Koufax of his generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australian Man to Be Charged in Parliament House Rape Case
description: Brittany Higgins had sent shock waves through the country when she said she was attacked by a co-worker in 2019.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Months after a former Australian government employee said she had been raped in Parliament House, the police announced on Friday that they intended to charge a man with sexual assault in the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Relief and Redemption as U.S. Women’s Volleyball Team Will Play for Gold
description: The Americans’ win over Serbia brought joy for the team, which lost to the Serbians five years ago in the semifinal at the 2016 Rio Games.
content: TOKYO — The morning of the Olympic women’s volleyball semifinal on Friday here at the Tokyo Games, Foluke Akinradewo, a three-time Olympian and middle blocker for the U.S. team, had a premonition: the United States was going to have a perfect match.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James C. McKinley Jr. and Lauren Hard
title: New Jersey’s governor orders schools to use masks.
description: The furious spread of the Delta variant has prompted mask mandates and fights between state and local authorities.
content: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey announced on Friday that in the face of the spreading, highly contagious Delta variant, all students, teachers, staff members and visitors would have to wear masks inside of school buildings when public schools open in a few weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Alan Rappeport
title: As Senate Vote Nears for $1 Trillion Infrastructure Bill, Deficit Takes a Back Seat
description: Many Republicans are disregarding the deficit impact for the sprawling infrastructure bill, but intend to change course for looming battles on social spending and the debt ceiling.
content: WASHINGTON — The bipartisan shrug that greeted the news that the Senate’s infrastructure bill contains $256 billion worth of deficit spending marked a new moment in the post-Trump era, one that highlighted how deficits matter only situationally to Republicans and inflation fears ebb and flow, depending on the politics of the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Ilona Royce Smithkin, a Muse in Fashion and Art, Dies at 101
description: After a troubling youth and a career teaching art, she sashayed into the roles of movie actress, cabaret singer, fashion model and artists’ mentor.
content: Ilona Royce Smithkin, who as an orange-haired nonagenarian with matching two-inch eyelashes caught fire in the world of fashion, starring in a documentary film and joining fashion campaigns for brands like Coach, while flinging embers into many other fields as a muse for photographers, filmmakers and entertainers, died on Aug. 1 at her home in Provincetown, Mass. She was 101.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Do We Make Things So Hard for Renters?
description: Relief came late, then slowly, and renters have been subject to political brinkmanship. We can do better.
content: For struggling homeowners in the pandemic’s first year, there was hope early on that these hard times would not put people with mortgages out in the street.

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: Kanye West Fans Turn Up at Donda Show ‘to See History Unfold’
description: Vintage and bootleg merch – plus some creative uses of masks – took center stage at a listening party in Atlanta.
content: ATLANTA — For the mile leading up to Mercedes-Benz Stadium, which these days might be better known as Kanye West’s new home, cars crawled along MLK Jr. Drive. Thousands of fans were on the way to listen to “Donda,” his long awaited 10th album. “Kanye got that downtown traffic jammin,” one local tweeted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Sharon LaFraniere
title: F.D.A. Aiming to Speed Extra Vaccine Doses for Immunocompromised Patients
description: Worried about a vulnerable population as the Delta variant surges, administration officials are taking a new tack.
content: The Food and Drug Administration is speeding efforts to authorize extra doses of the coronavirus vaccines for Americans with weakened immune systems, a change that reflects a growing concern within the Biden administration about these vulnerable patients as the contagious Delta variant surges nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Their Careers and Romance Took Root in Politics
description: Henry Connelly, the communications director for House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, and Samantha Warren, the chief of staff for Representative Bill Foster, became fast friends and confidants when they met in Washington.
content: Henry Connelly, the communications director for the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, can relate to the cinematic tale of a farmer discovering his “Field of Dreams” in an Iowa cornfield.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: A Rosé by Any Other Color
description: The palest shades have become the most popular, but can you discern anything meaningful by the hue? Three very different dark rosés argue otherwise.
content: The color of a wine can convey a lot about its character. But color is easy to misinterpret, and sometimes reveals less than it seems.
source.name: The New York Times

description: The Dixie fire tore through the Northern California community of Greenville. Plus, interviews with firefighters battling the blaze.

title: Italians (Mostly) Embrace a ‘Green Pass’ to Prove Vaccination on Its First Day
description: While such measures have prompted protests in France and divided Americans, Italians are enjoying a season of rationality under Prime Minister Mario Draghi.
content: ORBETELLO, Italy — On Friday, the first day that Italians needed to present a nationwide health passport for access to indoor dining, museums, gyms, theaters and a wide range of social activities, Margherita Catenuto, 18, from Sicily, proudly showed a bar code at the Capitoline Museum in Rome certifying that she was vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: What Is Going on With Obama’s 60th Birthday Bash?
description: The former president scaled back the guest list for his party on Martha’s Vineyard. Who’s in and who’s out?
content: Jay-Z and Beyoncé were still in, as of Friday.

title: In Qatar, the Olympic Team (Like Much Else) Is Mostly Imported
description: The small Gulf country, most of whose residents are foreign workers, has looked beyond its borders for athletes, too.
content: TOKYO — There is a lot of sand in Qatar but not a lot of beach parties. At least, not the kind of revelry that tends to draw beach volleyball players, in their bikinis and short shorts.

title: Tokyo Was Promised Glory and Riches. It Got an Olympics in a Bubble.

content: TOKYO — Tokyo’s leaders promised glory and riches when the Japanese capital won its bid to host the 2020 Summer Olympics. Jobs and the economy would grow. The public would rally in support. Japan’s international stature would rise.

title: Paul Cotton, Mainstay of the Country-Rock Band Poco, Dies at 78
description: He joined the band for its third album and expanded its emotional and stylistic palette with his sinewy, blues-inflected guitar work and brooding baritone vocals.

title: Canada’s Drought Is Forcing Farmers to Make Once-Unthinkable Choices
description: This summer has seen devastation across Western Canada with extreme weather, raging wildfires and drought threatening lives and livelihoods.
content: We’re halfway through the summer and since the beginning of the season, the effects of extreme weather in Western Canada have been relentless. The devastation in British Columbia and the Prairies, including raging wildfires and extreme drought, are threatening lives and livelihoods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Whippman
title: What We Are Not Teaching Boys About Being Human
description: It turns out that there is a bizarre absence of fully realized human beings in my sons’ fictional worlds.
content: A while back, at the bookstore with my three sons, I started flicking through a kids’ magazine that had the kind of hyper-pink sparkly cover that screams: “Boys! Even glancing in this direction will threaten your masculinity!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: How a Daddy Longlegs Grows Such Strange Legs
description: Scientists have identified genes that make a harvestman arachnid’s appendages able to twirl like a monkey’s tail.
content: The harvestman makes its way through the mossy woodland on eight spindly legs, delicate tentpoles supporting a plump body with two tiny eyes. These arachnids, sometimes called daddy longlegs, are cousins of spiders whose outdoorsy lifestyle sets them apart from the other creatures called daddy longlegs, which are more properly known as cellar spiders. They have other curious differences, too: The tips of a harvestman’s elegant limbs are flexible, allowing them to wrap around a twig like a monkey’s tail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘Aftershocks’ and ‘Here We Are’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: TRUE STORY, by Kate Reed Petty. (Penguin, 336 pp., $17.) “Horror, suspense, confessional, epistolary tale, recovery memoir, cautionary tale, even ... paranoiac noir — Petty leaps from genre to genre with dizzying velocity” to show “the way trauma works on us.” Our reviewer, Megan Abbott, called this novel about the “rippling impact” of an alleged sexual assault after a high school party nearly two decades earlier a “spellbinding debut.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Comforto
title: A Marriage Stressed by Obsessions and Compulsions
description: My husband was kind, honest, supportive and way too protective.
content: One morning, when our son was four months old, my husband noticed a little red spot on the boy’s lip. Like any sleep-deprived parent, my husband went to his computer and Googled “red spot on baby’s lip.” Twenty minutes later, he came back pale-faced and hyperventilating; he even had to put his head between his knees to keep from passing out. He had gone down a dark hole on the internet and found the story of a baby with a red spot on his lip who ended up tragically ill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Joao Silva
title: No Work, No Food: Pandemic Deepens Global Hunger
description: Relentless waves of the virus, combined with crises caused by conflict and climate change, have left tens of millions of people around the world on the brink of famine.
content: EAST LONDON, South Africa — Even as thousands died and millions lost their jobs when the Covid-19 pandemic engulfed South Africa last year, Thembakazi Stishi, a single mother, was able to feed her family with the steady support of her father, a mechanic at a Mercedes plant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Student-Athletes Can Now Earn Money. Here Are the Pitfalls.
description: College athletes have limited life experience and financial expertise, which makes them ripe for being taken advantage of, wealth advisers say.

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The Good and Bad News About the Delta Variant
description: A leading epidemiologist answers my biggest questions about the latest Covid-19 threat.
content: “The war has changed.” That’s what the leaked C.D.C. document says about the way the Delta variant has upended our coronavirus policies. Delta is astonishingly contagious. It can generate 1,000 times the viral load of the original coronavirus strain, and it spreads with the ease of chickenpox. The vaccinated can no longer assume immunity. The unvaccinated are at more risk than ever. Masks are back. New York City is essentially imposing a vaccine mandate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Andre Iguodala Plans to End His Career With Golden State
description: Iguodala said he plans to return on a one-year deal after a detour to the Miami Heat. “The opportunity to end it here was just something special,” he said.
content: Andre Iguodala found himself in recent months in discussions with his few N.B.A. peers remaining, the ones who sculpted paralleling journeys, from being teenagers to experiencing parenthood, from playing for free in high school gyms to playing for millions in front of thousands.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Presidencies are governed by events and priorities, and President Biden — propelled into office by epochal events in 2020 — has staked his political fortunes on passage of a $1 trillion infrastructure bill intended to demonstrate his competence, can-do attitude and commitment to bipartisanship.

title: It’s Not Just the Medal. It’s the Payout.

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Allyson Felix wins her 10th Olympic medal, tying an American record in her sport.
description: Felix has matched Carl Lewis as the most decorated American athlete in track and field.
content: TOKYO — With nine Olympic medals (six golds and three silvers), Felix was already tied with the Jamaican sprinter Merlene Ottey as the most decorated female Olympian in track and field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yewande Komolafe
title: The Gloriously Versatile Plantain
description: Every starch has its secrets. Here’s what makes plantains so exceptional.
content: Starches — legumes, tubers, grains, to name a few — are a motley bunch. But one thing they share is how they strike a delicate balance between firm and plump, and, well, dried out or mealy when cooked. One starch, though, is sturdy enough to withstand a little overcooking and can be prepared at any stage of ripeness: the gloriously versatile plantain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Hisako Ueno
title: Biting your own medal is one thing. A Japanese mayor learned you don’t bite someone else’s.
description: The mayor of Nagoya, Japan, apologized for a gesture that some called insulting and unhygienic amid the coronavirus pandemic.
content: Olympic athletes have long been photographed biting their medals, a celebratory if not entirely hygienic gesture.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Céline Gounder
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Céline Gounder. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Get Vaccinated. Get Masked. It’s the Only Way Out of This.
description: Until many more people get vaccinated, we’ll all need to keep our masks handy.
content: The United States is firmly entrenched in another coronavirus surge, and it seems that many leaders around the country still have not learned the most important lesson of the past 18 months: It takes quick, decisive action and clear communication to get ahead of this virus. Temporary restrictions now are the only way to avoid more stringent ones down the line. We know that masks work. That vaccines work. That mandates work. To keep schools, restaurants and other businesses and institutions open — and to bring the Delta variant to heel — communities will need to use all of those tools together.
source.name: The New York Times

title: United Airlines will require vaccination, and Amazon revives mask mandates.
description: United Airlines employees will be required to upload proof of vaccination within five weeks of the Food and Drug Administration’s fully approving a vaccine or by Oct. 25, whichever comes first.
content: United Airlines said on Friday that it would require all U.S. employees to be vaccinated against the coronavirus starting this fall. It was the first major airline to establish such a mandate and the latest in a small but growing number of businesses to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Finally.

title: Charged With Treason, a Genocide Survivor Opts to Fight, Not Flee
description: As a child, Theary Seng escaped Cambodia’s killing fields. After returning there as a human rights advocate, she angered the country’s strongman leader. But she refuses to be driven away again.
content: BANGKOK — Only a small child when the Khmer Rouge seized power in 1975 and soon made her an orphan, Theary Seng has two enduring memories from that time in Cambodia’s tortured history.

title: Jobs Surge in July Offers Fresh Sign of Economic Recovery
description: The gain of 943,000 was the best showing in nearly a year, and unemployment was 5.4 percent, the lowest since the pandemic began.
content: The American economy roared into midsummer with a strong gain in hiring, overcoming trouble in matching workers with openings, as the recovery appeared to take firmer hold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: As Covid Surges in Florida, DeSantis Refuses to Change Course
description: A virus spike connected to the Delta variant has led to a record number of Covid-19 hospitalizations in Florida. Gov. Ron DeSantis has not altered his approach, for better or worse.
content: MIAMI — Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida snapped this week at a reporter who asked if masks might help keep children safe in a state that now has more Covid-19 hospitalizations, including for pediatric patients, than anywhere else in the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Man Was Held for More Than 2 Years Over Mistaken Identity, His Lawyer Says
description: Joshua Spriestersbach was arrested in 2017 in Hawaii after a police officer thought he looked like a man who had an outstanding warrant, according to a petition to clear his record.
content: The long ordeal of Joshua Spriestersbach, a homeless man in Hawaii, began on May 11, 2017, when a Honolulu police officer woke him up and arrested him. He had fallen asleep as he waited in line to enter a shelter for food, but, instead, he was sent to a jail on Oahu for a crime he didn’t commit, according to a petition his lawyer filed this week seeking to clear his record.
source.name: The New York Times

title: After Deadly Floods, a German Village Rethinks Its Relationship to Nature
description: A long history of bad land use decisions exacerbated the death toll and damage of Germany’s recent megaflood. Some say now is the time to rebuild differently.
content: RECH, Germany — Shortly before midnight Dominik Gieler received one last WhatsApp message from his mother. She had watched as a tsunami of river first took one, then two, then all of the houses around her own. “I won’t make it out of here,” she told him.

title: Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, 84, Dies; Key Figure in Portugal Revolt
description: He became a national hero in the 1974 “Carnation Revolution,” which ousted a dictatorship. But he later landed in prison for links to a terrorist group.
content: Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, a Portuguese Army officer who helped mastermind the almost bloodless military overthrow of his country’s dictatorship in 1974 and later served a prison sentence on charges of inciting terrorism, died on July 25 in a military hospital in Lisbon. He was 84.

content: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, said the country would provide two billion Covid-19 vaccine doses to the world this year and would donate $100 million to a global effort to distribute the doses to developing countries, as Beijing attempts to take on a more prominent leadership role in curbing the pandemic.

description: Jamaica’s victory was expected. Italy’s was not.
content: The Jamaican women put an exclamation point on their domination of Olympic sprinting Friday night, winning the women’s 4x100 relay in a race whose outcome seemed predetermined from the start.

title: The Dixie Fire is now the largest blaze in the U.S., and third-largest wildfire on record in California.
description: It is the third-largest wildfire on record in California. Climate change is  increasing the size and intensity of Western fires.
content: The Dixie Fire exploded by more than 97,000 acres in 24 hours, becoming the third-largest wildfire on record in California by Friday. It had been only sixth on the list of blazes the day before.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A British BMX racer’s historic gold required a little financial help from her friends.
description: Bethany Shriever turned to a GoFundMe to reach her Olympic dreams.
content: When Bethany Shriever secured the gold medal in the women’s BMX racing final, it was in an event in which she was not even projected to be a finalist. The win last week was Britain’s first Olympic gold in the event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: 5 Science-Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: From a Swedish space probe to a self-reflective time-travel comedy, these new sci-fi picks offer a range of offbeat experiences.
content: Before you get to any of this month’s selection of off-the-beaten-path science fiction, do watch the trailer for “Trump vs. the Illuminati.” The plot summary starts with “A Chinese clone of 45th U.S. president Donald J. Trump survives the Earth’s destruction,” and that is pretty much all you need to know.

author: By Norman J. Ornstein
title: Don’t Be Fooled by Mitch McConnell’s Sudden Bout of Bipartisanship
description: The Senate minority leader is gearing up for months of obstruction. But Democrats can fight back.
content: Are we entering a new era of bipartisanship? On the surface, the news from Washington seems remarkably encouraging. The Senate is close to passing a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill, with $550 billion in new spending on everything from transit to highways to broadband to climate change mitigation. Political insiders are hailing the bill as a breakthrough, with the Senate poised, at last, to overcome the partisan gridlock that has ground its legislative machinery to a halt. Many thought that President Biden’s belief that he could get Republican votes was naïve, but he delivered. In a surprise, even the Senate minority leader, Mitch McConnell, voted to move the compromise to a vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Together for Each Other in Sickness, Health and New Locks
description: Brittany Muszynski, a breast cancer survivor, met Mickey Majzik at the altar in a lace mermaid gown and a wig donated by the New Jersey foundation Wigs & Wishes.
content: Brittany Muszynski remembers the old saying about all brides being beautiful. But when her own wedding was approaching, she started doubting it. “I thought, ‘I’m going to feel so ugly when I get married,’” she said.

author: By Steven Greenhouse
title: A Labor Leader Is Gone, and the Road Ahead for Unions Is Steep
description: Richard Trumka, the late leader of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., breathed life into the American labor movement. But the road ahead is ominous.
content: In many ways, A.F.L.-C.I.O. President Richard Trumka, who died of a heart attack on Thursday, was an old-line union leader. His grandfather and father were coal miners. And he, too, worked in the mines before going to law school. He once led one of the nation’s oldest and most tradition-bound unions, the United Mine Workers. He had another old-line attribute — he was a truculent fighter who didn’t give up easily, once leading a ten-month strike by 1,700 miners against Pittston Coal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How the Owner of a 24/7 Diner Spends Her Sundays
description: Irene Siderakis feeds New Yorkers all day at work, then comes home and provides dinner for her four adolescent sons.
content: Three years ago, Irene Siderakis, a stay-at-home mom, suddenly inherited Kellogg’s Diner, a 24-hour go-to for eggs, burgers, nachos, Greek staples and more in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Chris Siderakis, her husband and the diner’s previous owner, had died unexpectedly, at 49. “I had no idea how to run a diner or if I could,” she said. “I had to make a choice: sell the diner or learn the business on my own and show my boys we can do this and persevere.” She opted for the latter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Push to Return 116,000 Native American Remains Is Long-Awaited
description: Changes to U.S. regulations would seek to eliminate red tape that has delayed the return of burial remains and sacred objects held by museums and other institutions.
content: In 1990, when Congress passed a law that set criteria under which federally recognized Native American tribes could reclaim ancient burial remains and sacred objects, legislators hoped to encourage the return of items by museums and other institutions. But more than three decades later, some officials acknowledge that the law, known as the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act, or NAGPRA, has not been as effective as they had hoped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: Married to a Worrier

content: Even if you’re not usually an anxious person, it’s common to feel worry, doubt and even fear in times of uncertainty. However, excessive worrying can often drive a wedge between you and your loved ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Myrlie Evers and Henry Scott Wallace
title: Our Families Fought for Civil Rights. Don’t Let Jim Crow Stand.
description: Family members of civil rights icon Medgar Evers and former Vice President Henry A. Wallace lament the filibuster in light of their loved ones' life and work.
content: I’m Myrlie Evers. Right before he was murdered, my husband, Medgar Evers, told me, “Don’t ever give up on those things that you believe in.” Medgar and I had a transcendent connection, and these words have lifted my spirits throughout the decades-long fight for justice against Medgar’s assassin, my time at the N.A.A.C.P. and my run for Congress against a far-right extremist. Now, those words guide me whenever I see things Medgar fought and died for being erased by misguided politicians.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Olympians are the world’s most impressive athletes. content: Kendall Anne Michaelis and Michael Joseph Harrell started out as high school sweethearts. They met and began dating in 2005 when he was a junior and she was a sophomore at Wheeler High School in Marietta, Ga. And like many high school sweethearts, Ms. Michaelis, 31, and Mr. Harrell, 32, were off again on again through college. Afterward, she headed for New York City, and he went the University of Georgia School of Law.

content: Patricia Wilde, a principal dancer known for her speed and daring as a member of George Balanchine’s New York City Ballet in its early years, and later an influential teacher and artistic director, died on July 17 in Stephens City, Va. She was 93.

author: By Adam Bradley
title: The Timeless Appeal of Tommie Smith, Who Knew a Podium Could Be a Site of Protest
description: In 1968, he and John Carlos raised their fists during an Olympic medal ceremony. Their demonstration still inspires athletes, artists and marginalized people everywhere.
content: THE STREET VENDORS along 125th Street in Harlem sell all manner of things: perfume and watches, shea butter and cellphone accessories, paperback books and, of course, T-shirts. One memorable shirt shows three athletes on the medal stand: a white man looking straight ahead and two Black men with heads bowed and arms outstretched, their black-gloved fists raised high in the air. It’s a familiar image, even 53 years after the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City, at which the American sprinters Tommie Smith and John Carlos staged one of the most iconic protests of the last century.

Watering it down to achieve bipartisan support would have been a “mistake,” Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, said at the time, one that Democrats would not be making again.
